pullRequest.body:
This adds a folder `NumberTheory.EulerProduct` and within it the file `Basic.lean`, which contains some general results on Euler products (for functions from the naturals into a complete normed field, with suitable properties).

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

bors merge
Thanks for making these changes – looks good to me now!
Thanks for making these changes – looks good to me now!

Thanks!

bors merge

tiny golf:
```suggestion
 rw [dist_eq_norm, norm_sub_rev, prod_primesBelow_tsum_eq_tsum_smoothNumbers hf₁ hmul hsum m]
```
OK.

```suggestion
    exact ⟨(Set.finite_singleton 1).summable (‖f ·‖), hf₁ ▸ hasSum_singleton 1 f⟩
```
OK.

Oddly, it looks like 
```lean
have := summable_mul_of_summable_norm (hsum hN) ih.1
exact this
```
works fine. Maybe worth asking on zulip about this?
See [here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/Proving.20a.20sum.20over.20smooth.20numbers.20is.20summable/near/400602151).
Oh well; another one for the "known bugs" file.
I don't like the name here, since (to number theorists) "multiplicative" usually means weakly, not completely, multiplicative.
Which names for the two results would you suggest instead?
Maybe one should become `eulerProduct_completely_multiplicative`?
OK.

Do you actually use the fact that F is a field, for the general results on weakly (not completely) multiplicative functions? Would any commutative complete normed ring work? (I very much doubt the additional generality would be useful for anything, of course.)

It seems that `norm_mul` and `norm_pow` need a division ring (and it has to be commutative for other reasons). This is maybe an artifact of the way a norm is defined. Possibly one can get by with just using upper bounds instead of equalities; I'll check.

> It seems that norm_mul and norm_pow need a division ring

That's kind of annoying – it would be nice if there was a type class for "ring with a _multiplicative_ [semi?]-norm" – but this is not the place to fix it. I definitely don't think it's worth adding extra work and complication to the proofs for no obvious application.

It was not that painful (I had to add a line using `Summable.of_nonneg_of_le` in two places), so I have reduced the requirements to the target being a complete normed commutative ring for the general statement. It then made sense to re-arrange the material so that everything related to the general statement comes  before everything related to the statement for completely multiplicative functions. Unfortunately, this makes the diff fairly large.

There are already general definitions of weakly / strongly multiplicative functions in mathlib, in the `ArithmeticFunction` file. (I'm not saying we absolutely have to use those constructs here, of course, but we should be on guard against accidental duplication of existing functionality.)
It probably makes sense to add versions where `f` is of type `Nat.ArithmeticFunction`. I don't think I've seen a notion of completely multiplicative arithmetic functions in that file, though.

> I don't think I've seen a notion of completely multiplicative arithmetic functions in that file, though

That's covered by the general MonoidHom classes (as you observed); it's the weakly multiplicative ones which are slightly verbose to write out directly, so picking up and using an existing definition might well shorten the code. (I'm not sure I like the design of the `ArithmeticFunction` class much, so if you don't like it either, feel free not to use it; I just thought I'd mention that it's there.)

I was thinking of adding a version like `Nat.ArithmeticFunction.IsMultiplicative.eulerProduct` so that one could do `f_isMul.eulerProduct <proof of norm-summability>` (instead of refactoring what I have; I think it makes sense to have an unbundled version as well).
I've added that now.
Isn't it simpler to just open this globally throughout the file?
Probably. I'll change that.

Since "Euler product" is atomic, namingwise, I suggest to call this `eulerProduct`.
```suggestion
theorem eulerProduct (hf₀ : f 0 = 0) :
```
If you agree, please make the corresponding adaptation below.
Will do. (Breathing a sigh of relief that you didn't propose `tendsto_prod_primesBelow_tsum_nat_comp_pow_atTop_tsum_nat_of_multiplicative_of_summable_norm` or so :smile: )
OK.

This should probably move to another file?
Even the lemma above I'm not sure about, but seems more specialist so I'd be happy if there was no other good place for that one

OK, moving it into `Mathlib.NumberTheory.SmoothNumbers`.

Regarding the first lemma, `#find_home!` suggests `Mathlib.Analysis.SpecificLimits.Normed` (where `summable_geometric_iff_norm_lt_1` is stated, which is used in the proof). But I think it doesn't fit so well there, since it is about a monoid homomorphism.
Yeah I figure anything making use of both additive and multiplicative structures of the naturals belongs in number theory somewhere anyway ;)
